Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Development and Application of Multi-scale Modeling for Biomolecular Association

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to investigate complex interactions among molecules, including proteins, enzymes and nanoparticles using computer modeling. Understanding association processes will increase fundamental understanding of protein-ligand binding and its applications. Along with binding, molecule's kinetic behavior - how they move - also plays a crucial role in understanding how rapidly they interact, undergo change, and bind with one another. Traditional approaches in protein binding and enzymology typically focus on a final chemical-protein structure, instead of the kinetic and binding processes that precede that final stage. Yet, exploring binding processes deepens our understanding of how molecules recognize binding partners, and will guide molecular designs and engineering of enzymes for more efficient chemical catalysis. Simulations have provided powerful tools to study molecular associations. However, real molecular systems are quite complicated, and these tools are usually either very time consuming or tend to over-simplify a biological system. This project will combine multi-level coarse-grained and atomistic simulations to efficiently and accurately model molecular associations and kinetic enhancement of the enzymes and nanoparticle systems. Reliable and efficient molecular simulations play an ever-increasing role in studying binding kinetics. They provide unique insights into the mechanisms of biomolecular activity, an in the integration and interpretation of experiments. In addition, understanding binding kinetics contributes to the design of novel molecules and engineering enzymes and enzyme complexes for more efficient chemical activity. Successful completion of this research will improve understanding of protein-ligand binding kinetics and assist the design of nanostructures, nanoparticles and engineered enzymes.

This project will train young scientists, including graduate, undergraduate, and high school students. Seminars and summer courses will be organized to train students from the local colleges, high schools and UC Riverside. The outreach program will broaden participation of underrepresented groups by supporting under-represented minority students in science. Summer courses and seminars will introduce the field of computational chemistry and provide hands-on help for students doing research in the PI's laboratory. The results of this project will be integrated into regular courses at UCR and in special courses/seminars. The methods developed in the project will deepen understanding of protein-ligand recognition and binding kinetics. These are important in molecular design; therefore, the work will have practical benefits in various areas such as chemistry, biology, engineering and environmental sciences.

Institution.Name: University of California-Riverside
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Molecular association, in which two or more molecules find one another, is the first critical step for all biochemical catalysis and protein-ligand binding. Revealing the association processes brings fundamental understanding in protein?ligand binding and their applications. While experiments provide protein structures and measurements of molecular binding constants, we need atomistic details to uncover binding processes. Reliable and efficient molecular simulations play an ever-increasing role in investigating protein conformational changes, protein allostery, substrate channeling, gating, water effects and advantages of spatially organized multi-enzymes complexes. Over the past a few years, we have developed multi-level coarse-grained and atomistic simulations to efficiently and accurately model molecular associations and kinetic enhancement of our enzymes and nanoparticle systems. We have developed a new Brownian dynamics simulation package, GeomBD, which is particularly powerful to model substrate diffusion during a colocalized multi-step enzyme system, in a membrane environment, and a chamber with flow and without flow to transport/diffuse molecules. We have published our 2nd version, GeomBD2, and the package and source codes are available for the scientific community.

 

Traditional views in molecular recognition and enzymology typically focus on a final chemical-protein structure in the catalytic/binding site. For enhanced enzyme catalysis, we demonstrated that the concentration near the active site of an enzyme can affect the overall catalytic rate constants. Our experimental collaborator used non-specific intermolecular attraction to increase substrate concentration near the enzyme, and our simulations observed the local concentration effects to further interpret experimental data. We also carried out detailed atomistic studies to understand how a single residue mutation on the protein surface of the α-subunit tryptophan synthase can increase the overall synthetic rate of tryptophan. Our modeling work illustrated a noncovalent interaction network that coordinates the catalytic cycle of the enzyme. Our work provides unique insights into the mechanisms of biomolecular activity, and the findings are integrated into the design idea to create novel engineering enzymes and enzyme complexes for more efficient chemical catalysis.

 

 

The results of our work were disseminated through publication of peer-reviewed articles, and our group members presented seminars at local, national and international conferences and academic institutions. We organized hands-on computational chemistry/biology summer workshop that introduced computational biophysics, modeling and computer aided ligand/enzyme design to local community colleges and University students. Over the past five years, a number of graduate, undergraduate and high school students were trained in state-of-the-art techniques of chemistry, physics, biology and computer science, enabling a strong technological base to support the future needs of both industry and research laboratories.


Last Modified: 05/02/2021
Modified by: Chia-En A Chang
